node.title: Trustpower warns of cash flow pressures as it develops new projects
node.description: Trustpower shareholders are in for a windfall as it sells its retail arm, but the company is warning of some cash flow pressure ahead.

node.title: 'A pandemic is not the way to tackle climate change'
node.description: Climate Change Minister James Shaw says the latest report shows we cannot rely on a pandemic to cut emissions, and National's Christopher Luxon says more may need to be done.

node.title: Food price annual increase highest in over 10 years
node.description: Food prices were 7.6 percent higher in March than the year before - the biggest annual increase since the year ended July 2011.

node.title: "Nobody will ever be able to fill the shoes of Tā Toby"
node.description: After 16 years, the chair of the Te Arawa Lakes Trust, Sir Toby Curtis, has decided to step down.

node.title: Queenstown Lakes mayor Jim Boult not standing for re-election
node.description: Boult has served two terms as mayor since winning election in 2016 and says the decision came after lengthy consideration and discussions with his family,

node.title: Marsden Point refinery protest scales back
node.description: The organiser of a protest outside the former Marsden Point oil refinery insists anti-vax campaigners have left.

node.title: 'The sea level is not going to rise so don't worry about it'
node.description: A Westport Rating Joint Committee discussion on the town's proposed flood protection scheme has prompted regional council chairman Allan Birchfield to claim "the sea level is not going to rise so…

node.title: Trading halt placed on King Salmon ahead of full year result release
node.description: Marlborough-based King Salmon has been placed in a trading halt ahead of the scheduled release of its full year result and a potential capital raising.

node.title: Sherri Papini admits to faking her 2016 kidnapping
node.description: "I am deeply ashamed of myself for my behavior," Papini said in a statement.

node.title: 'Stupid and uneducated' ruling: ACC may not cover public holiday wages
node.description: An overhaul of the Holidays Act has thrown up a new, curly problem that could cost employers.

node.title: Backers defend plans for offshore wind energy project off Taranaki coast
node.description: The backers of a new wind energy project off the Taranaki coast believe the eyewatering costs of their technology will come down by the time work starts - that is if it goes ahead.

node.title: Commercial landlord gives tenant one-star review over vax passes
node.description: An Auckland bar that has continued to use vaccine passes has received a one star Facebook review from its own landlord.

node.title: Gisborne flooding partially closes State Highway 35
node.description: Flooding in the Gisborne region has closed State Highway 35 in two places between Hicks Bay and Te Araroa, and between Tokomaru Bay and Te Puia Springs. Audio

node.title: Diabetes and me: Making sustainable changes
node.description: My health is maybe not something I can fix in three months but if it isn't something I am being graded on, how will I know I have done well? RNZ's Megan Whelan shares her journey of learning to live…

node.title: Russian oligarch's superyacht sailing towards Fiji
node.description: A sanctioned Russian oligarch's superyacht is reportedly refuelling in Fiji this week - possibly the closest any will come to New Zealand.

node.title: Public transport ultimately 'can't be subsidised or underwritten' - Christopher Luxon
node.description: The case for ongoing public transport subsidies does not stack up, National Party leader Christopher Luxon says.

node.title: Worst yet to come as East Coast braces for heavy rain
node.description: People in Gisborne and Hawke's Bay are gearing up for a day of heavy rain as former Cyclone Fili bears down on the country. Audio

node.title: 'It's going to build slowly': Queenstown looks to ski season tourist influx
node.description: Australians can now enter the country without isolating, but Queenstown tourism businesses aren't expecting a return en masse until the ski season.

node.title: Tamariki Māori going unprotected against Covid-19
node.description: Most Te Tai Tokerau schools are not holding onsite Covid-19 vaccination clinics due to concerns about anti-vax retaliation.

node.title: Two men who posed as federal agents set to be released to home confinement
node.description: The FBI says that the two men tried to duped Secret Service officials and gave them gifts including rent-free apartments, iPhones and a drone, among other items.

node.title: Ukraine war: NZ Defence Force Hercules leaves for Europe on aid mission
node.description: A New Zealand Defence Force Hercules has taken off for Europe on a deployment to distribute donated military aid for Ukraine.

node.title: Forestry sector hopes fumigation alternative unlocks Indian market
node.description: The forestry sector is hopeful exports to India will resume now the Environmental Protection Authority has approved a new fumigation product for export logs.

node.title: Pfizer offers $100m to buy Brisbane firm behind app that diagnoses Covid-19
node.description: Pfizer has offered $100 million to buy a Brisbane-based company that has invented a smartphone app it says can diagnose Covid-19 by listening to someone cough.

node.title: 'G'day and welcome': First flights arrive as border reopens to Australians
node.description: There have been emotional scenes at Auckland Airport as the border reopened and the first flights from across the Tasman landed.

node.title: Cost blowout for Melling to Petone shared path
node.description: The cost of a cycle and walkway being built in Lower Hutt has doubled to $63m, or about $12m per kilometre.

node.title: As Covid-19 numbers fall, traffic light setting decision to be announced
node.description: The government is set to reveal today whether any part of the country will drop to the orange traffic light setting in time for Easter.

node.title: International hunters expected to target Aotearoa from next year
node.description: The border reopening is too late for this deer hunting season, but bookings for next year are already flooding in.

node.title: Greens: Ukraine weapons fund should be humanitarian relief
node.description: Money pledged toward weapons for Ukraine would be better spent on humanitarian relief the Green Party says.

node.title: NASA takes third crack at moon rocket countdown test
node.description: The test was delayed twice following a series of unrelated glitches.

node.title: Biden says Putin committing "genocide half a world away"
node.description: President Biden made the "genocide" comment during a speech on price increases in Iowa.
